docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 8

  • Prep time: 10 minutes
  • Cook time: 40 minutes
  • Total time: 50 minutes
  • EGG setup: two-zone grilling (indirect then direct)
  • EGG target temperature: 250F indirect, 500F for sear

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Reverse-seared picanha for a Brazilian steakhouse-style roast on the Big Green Egg.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2.5 lb picanha roast
  • BBQ rub (or salt, pepper, and garlic)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Preheat the Big Green Egg to 250F using a two-zone setup.
  2. Trim the silver skin and extra fat from the meat side of the picanha.
  3. Crosshatch the fat cap.
  4. Season both sides with your rub.
  5. Grill the roast on the indirect side until the internal temperature reaches 120F.
  6. Open the vents to bring the direct side to about 500F.
  7. Sear fat side down for 90 seconds, then fat side up for 90 seconds.
  8. Rest for 10 minutes, slice, and serve.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 24 (about 150 g portions using a 7.3 kg roast)

  • Prep time: 75 minutes
  • Cook time: 4-6 hours
  • Total time: 7 hours 15 minutes
  • EGG setup: indirect smoke
  • EGG target temperature: 225-250F

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3.6-7.3 kg beef ribeye roast

Herb paste:

  • 59 ml olive oil
  • 28 g kosher salt
  • 28 g freshly ground black pepper
  • 14 g finely chopped fresh rosemary
  • 14 g finely chopped fresh thyme
  • 14 g finely chopped fresh sage

Garnish:

  • 14 g finely chopped fresh parsley (optional)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Combine the herb paste ingredients and spread evenly over the roast at least 1 hour before cooking. Bring the roast to room temperature before it goes on the EGG.
  2. Preheat the smoker to 225-250F.
  3. Add wood chunks or pellets for smoke as desired.
  4. Insert a thermometer into the thickest part of the roast without touching bone or fat. Place the roast rib side down and smoke for 4-6 hours, or until the internal temperature reaches 135-140F for medium rare or 155F for medium.
  5. Rest under a foil tent for 15-20 minutes (the temperature will rise about 5F).
  6. Carve between the ribs. For thinner slices, remove the ribs first.
  7. Season with salt and parsley as desired.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• For medium rare, pull at 135-140F. For medium, pull at 155F.
  • Leftovers portion well for sandwiches or ready-to-eat meals.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen Steak Reverse Sear Method
Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• EGG setup: indirect, then direct for sear
  • EGG target temperature: 225F indirect, 550F for sear

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Steak:

  • The Four Saucemen The Beef Rub
  • Best steak you can buy (tomahawk rib eyes are great for a party)
  • Flaky sea salt, to season
  • Olive oil, for coating

Steak butter:

  • 250 g butter
  • 1 large shallot, finely diced
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1/2 cup flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
  • 1/4 cup sage, finely chopped
  • 1/4 cup tarragon, finely chopped
  • 1/2 tsp finely grated lemon zest
  • 1 tsp ground black pepper
  • Salt, to taste

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Mix the steak butter ingredients. Roll in food wrap into logs and freeze what you do not need.
  2. Set up the Big Green Egg for indirect cooking at 225F with two pieces of smoking wood.
  3. Cook the beef from room temperature. Coat lightly with olive oil and apply a fine layer of beef rub 10 minutes before grilling.
  4. Once the EGG is stable at 225F, place the steak in the center of the grill. Turn every 10 minutes.
  5. For a 6 cm thick steak, expect about 45-50 minutes to reach medium-rare. Target internal temperatures: 115-120F rare, 125-130F medium rare, 135F medium.
  6. Remove the steak and rest under a tented foil.
  7. Carefully remove the ConvEGGtor. Open the vents and heat the EGG to 550F. Preheat cast iron or grill grates if you have them.
  8. Sear the steaks for 1 minute per side, turning at 30 seconds for diamond marks.
  9. Top with steak butter while resting and season with flaky sea salt if needed.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Reverse sear works best for steaks thicker than 3 cm, especially scotch fillet or rib eye.
  • The recipe does not recommend cooking past medium.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Cheeks
Overview
docs.text: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Cheeks

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Beef Rub
  • 2-6 beef cheeks
  • Olive oil (binder)
  • Foil tray large enough for the cheeks
  • Foil to cover the tray
  • Dark beer
  • Beef broth
  • 1 onion, chopped
  • One great bottle of red for the chef

docs.title: Spritz
docs.text:
• 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

Mix in a spray bottle.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Open a beer (repeat if necessary) and a good bottle of red to breathe.
  2. Set your BBQ or smoker for indirect cooking at 250-275F with two pieces of smoking wood. We used Pohutukawa.
  3. About 30 minutes before smoking, trim any silver skin and hard fat from the cheeks.
  4. Lightly coat with olive oil and apply The Four Saucemen Beef Rub on all sides.
  5. Place the cheeks on the BBQ (use a drip pan). Smoke uncovered for 2.5 hours for small cheeks (about 500 g) or about 4 hours for large cheeks (about 1 kg). Spritz every hour.
  6. The cheeks should be dark brown. If using a probe thermometer, expect around 150-160F.
  7. Prepare a foil tray with dark beer, beef broth, and chopped onion (wine, port, or beef stock also work). You want 15-20 mm of liquid in the base. Use room-temperature liquids.
  8. Place the cheeks in the tray, cover tightly with foil, and braise. If using a Bluetooth thermometer, insert it before covering.
  9. Return the tray to the BBQ until the internal temperature reaches about 210F, usually 2.5-4 hours depending on size.
  10. Carefully uncover and check doneness. The probe should slide in with almost no resistance. For slicing, cook until about 205F instead.

These are great for tacos, quesadillas, or served with a simple salad. This method also works for beef shin.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Short Ribs
Overview
docs.text: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Short Ribs (8-9 hour cook)

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Beef Rub
  • Beef short ribs (Wakanui, Ocean Beef, Silver Fern Farms Reserve, or similar)
  • Olive oil (binder)

docs.title: Spritz
docs.text:
• 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

Mix in a spray bottle.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Open a beer (repeat if necessary).
  2. Remove the ribs from the fridge and bring to room temperature.
  3. Trim the top side to expose the meat under the fat. Remove any silver skin.
  4. Set your Big Green Egg or smoker for indirect cooking at 250-275F with two pieces of smoking wood. We used Pohutukawa for beef.
  5. About 10 minutes before smoking, apply a thin layer of olive oil and a light coat of The Four Saucemen Beef Rub.
  6. Place the ribs on the Egg, bone side down. Smoke uncovered and spritz every 1.5 hours.
  7. Cook until internal temperature is around 200F, about 8-9 hours. Probe with a bamboo skewer; it should feel like very soft butter with little resistance.
  8. Once it probes tender all over, cook for another hour.
  9. Remove and rest for 10 minutes.

Beef short ribs are extremely fatty and delicious. A chimichurri (Jess Pryles recipe) is a great dressing to cut through the richness.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Four Saucemen Brisket Steps ("The Holy Grail of BBQ")

This recipe is designed for a 6-10 kg brisket.

docs.title: Choosing Your Brisket
docs.text: There is now a great selection of brisket available in NZ: small to large, grass-fed, grain-finished Wagyu, Aussie imports, and USA briskets. Look for good fat, marbling, and a thick flat. If you are unsure, ask your butcher. The point end is fatty and forgiving; the flat is where most of us get frustrated.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Beef Rub
  • 1 large whole brisket (Snake River Farms USA, Wakanui NZ, Ocean Beef NZ, First Light NZ, or Black Onyx AUS)
  • Olive oil (binder)
  • Foil tray large enough to fit the brisket
  • Foil to cover the tray or quality peach paper
  • Dark beer
  • Beef broth or stock
  • 1 onion, chopped
  • One great bottle of red for the chef and a couple of beers for good measure

docs.title: Spritz
docs.text:
• 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

Mix in a spray bottle.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Open a beer (repeat if necessary) and a good bottle of red to breathe. Every brisket varies by breed, fat content, and size.
  2. Set your BBQ or smoker for indirect cooking at 250-275F with smoking wood. We used oak in a Lonestar Grillz offset and hickory on a Big Green Egg. If your brisket looks lean, run a lower temp.
  3. Allow the brisket to come to room temperature (this can take hours). Trim any silver skin and hard fat, leaving the softer fat to protect the meat. About 30 minutes before cooking, lightly coat with olive oil and apply The Four Saucemen Beef Rub on all sides.
  4. Smoke uncovered for about 4 hours. Fat side up on an offset, fat side down on the Big Green Egg. Use a drip pan. Spritz every hour. The bark should be dark brown and set (it should not smudge when you gently rub it). Internal temperature is typically around 150-160F at this stage.
  5. Prepare a foil tray with dark beer, beef broth, and chopped onion (wine, port, or beef stock also work). You want 15-20 mm of liquid in the base, and the liquids should be room temperature. Place the brisket in the tray, insert a temp probe if using one, and cover tightly with foil. Alternatively, wrap in quality peach paper with some of the liquid and onion.
  6. Return the covered brisket to the smoker. When internal temperature reaches around 200F, start checking the feel.
  7. Probe with an instant-read thermometer. It should slide in like room-temperature butter with little resistance. Check the point and the flat. Internal temps can vary from 200F to 215F; feel matters most.
  8. Rest: Unwrap and let the brisket sit in the juices so steam can escape (at least 15 minutes). Rewrap, cover with a towel, and rest in a cooler/chilli bin/esky for about 2 hours if you can wait.
  9. Slice the flat across the grain. Use the point for burnt ends or slices.

Brisket is extremely versatile: burgers, soups, pies, pizza topping, or freshly sliced on white bread with a little reduced gravy and mustard.

docs.title: Tri Tip with Blue Cheese Smoked Paprika Butter
Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 8

  • Prep time: 10 minutes
  • Cook time: 40 minutes
  • Total time: 50 minutes
  • EGG setup: indirect, then direct for sear
  • EGG target temperature: 350F indirect, 500-600F for sear

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.7 kg tri tip
  • Freshly ground NY cut pepper
  • Flaky sea salt or kosher salt (smoked sea salt works too)
  • Smoked paprika
  • Garlic powder
  • Optional: your favorite rub

Blue cheese smoked paprika butter:

  • 4 oz blue cheese
  • 1 stick butter, softened
  • Fresh ground pepper
  • 1 tbsp smoked paprika

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Prepare the EGG for 350F indirect heat using the deflector.
  2. Season the tri tip with salt, pepper, garlic, paprika, or your favorite rub.
  3. Smoke on indirect heat for 20-30 minutes, until internal temperature reaches 120-127F.
  4. Rest under a foil tent.
  5. Raise the EGG temperature to 500-600F and sear each side for about 2 minutes, aiming for 127-130F for medium rare.
  6. Rest for 10 minutes, slice, and serve with the blue cheese butter.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The thinner end cooks faster; monitor internal temperature closely.
  • This roast is best cooked to medium rare rather than well done.

docs.title: Chicken
docs.text:
• Korean Glazed Chicken Thighs
  • The Four Saucemen Friday Night Chicken Wings

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Sticky-sweet, charcoal-grilled chicken thighs basted with a gochujang fruit glaze.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Recipe type: Korean charcoal BBQ
  • Cuisine: Korean
  • Prep time: 10 minutes
  • Cook time: 15 minutes
  • Total time: 25 minutes
  • Serves: 12

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Chicken:

  • 12 boneless, skinless chicken thighs
  • 24 wooden or stainless steel skewers (2 per thigh, hibachi style)
  • Duck fat spray (or any neutral oil spray)
  • Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

Gochujang basting:

  • 113 g gochujang (Korean chili paste)
  • 133 ml soy sauce
  • 56 g honey (or agave nectar)
  • 56 g rice wine vinegar
  • 2 g kosher salt
  • 4 g freshly ground black pepper
  • 1 green apple, peeled
  • 1 nashi pear, peeled
  • 50 g fresh pineapple (optional)
  • 18 g garlic cloves
  • 18 g fresh ginger, peeled
  • 1 small red onion, finely diced
  • Water, as needed to loosen

Garnish:

  • 1 scallion, finely sliced
  • 1 sprig fresh coriander, leaves only
  • 5 g toasted sesame seeds

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. If using wooden skewers, soak in water for at least 30 minutes.
  2. Trim any cartilage from the thighs. Season with salt, pepper, and a light spray of duck fat.
  3. Thread each thigh on two skewers about 25 mm apart. Refrigerate on a tray until ready to grill.
  4. Blend gochujang, soy sauce, honey, vinegar, ginger, and garlic until smooth.
  5. Add apple and pear; blend again until smooth. Add pineapple if using.
  6. Stir in diced red onion. Add a splash of water if you need to thin the basting.
  7. Preheat charcoal to 390-400 F (200 C). Hibachi, yakitori, or kettle grills work well.
  8. Grill thighs, turning once they color. Begin basting after the first flip.
  9. Continue flipping and basting until the internal temperature reaches 159 F (70 C).
  10. Rest 3-5 minutes, then garnish with scallion, coriander, and sesame seeds.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen Friday Night Chicken Wings
Overview
docs.text: Slow-smoked, then hot-crisped wings finished in buffalo sauce.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• Chicken wings, as many as you need (larger wings are best)
  • The Four Saucemen Chicken Rub
  • Culley's Buffalo Wing Sauce (No. 2 for mild heat, No. 6 for hot)
  • Duck fat spray or olive oil spray
  • Smoking wood (oak recommended)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Separate wings into flappers and drummies. Discard tips.
  2. Place on a rack over a tray and refrigerate uncovered overnight to dry the skin (optional but improves crispness).
  3. Set up for indirect cooking at 225 F with smoking wood. Use a foil tray under the grill to catch fat.
  4. Lightly spray wings and coat all sides with the chicken rub.
  5. Smoke wings, turning every 10 minutes, until they reach about 155 F internal (30-40 minutes depending on size).
  6. Toss wings in buffalo sauce.
  7. Open vents and raise grill to 450 F. Return wings to the grill and cook until crisp and 175-185 F internal.

docs.title: Desserts
docs.text: • Baked Cheesecake

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 8-16

  • Prep time: 30 minutes
  • Cook time: 120 minutes
  • Total time: 26 hours (includes 24-hour chill)
  • EGG setup: indirect
  • EGG target temperature: 350F, then 325F

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Crust:

  • 2 1/2 cups crushed graham cracker crumbs (about 210 g)
  • 1/4 cup sugar (50 g)
  • 3/4 cup butter, melted (170 g)

Cheesecake filling:

  • 4 x 8 oz (905 g) packages cream cheese, at room temperature
  • 1 1/3 cups sugar (267 g)
  • 4 large eggs, at room temperature
  • 1 1/3 cups sour cream (327 g)
  • 3 tsp vanilla extract

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Set up the EGG for indirect cooking with the ConvEGGtor at 350F.
  2. Mix the crust ingredients until they hold together. Wrap foil around the bottom of a springform pan to prevent leaks.
  3. Press the crust into the pan, up about 1 inch on the sides, and bake 10-15 minutes until edges are lightly golden. Cool for 30 minutes.
  4. Lower the EGG temperature to 325F.
  5. Beat cream cheese on medium until smooth (about 5 minutes). Add sugar and mix until combined.
  6. Add eggs one at a time, mixing until the yellow disappears after each addition.
  7. Stir in sour cream and vanilla on low or with a spatula until just combined.
  8. Pour filling into the crust and smooth the top.
  9. Bake about 1.5 hours until the top is just golden.
  10. Cool on a rack for 2-3 hours without opening the springform pan.
  11. Cover with plastic wrap pressed onto the cheesecake and refrigerate for 24 hours.
  12. Top with fresh strawberries and serve.

docs.title: Lamb
docs.text:
• Four Saucemen NZ Lamb Rack
  • Weekend Lamb Ribs

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 2-4 people

  • EGG setup: indirect, then direct for sear
  • Recommended charcoal: oak, cherry, or hickory
  • EGG target temperature: 225°F (107°C) indirect, then 550°F (288°C) for sear
  • Cooking time: 35-60 minutes plus 15 minutes rest

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 lamb rack (NZ lamb preferred)
  • Olive oil (binder)
  • The Four Saucemen Lamb Rub
  • Sea salt (optional, to finish)

docs.title: Equipment
docs.text:
• ConvEGGtor or other indirect setup
  • Drip pan or aluminum tray
  • Instant-read thermometer
  • Tongs

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This is a reverse-seared lamb rack: low-and-slow over indirect heat to build smoke flavor, then a fast, high-heat sear to finish the crust.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Trim the lamb rack. Remove the silver skin and clean the bones. If leaving the fat cap on, score it lightly. Wrap the bones in foil to protect them from over-browning.
  2. Lightly coat the lamb with olive oil, then apply The Four Saucemen Lamb Rub generously on all sides.
  3. Set up the EGG for indirect cooking at 225°F (107°C). Add one chunk of smoking wood and place a drip pan under the grate.
  4. Cook the lamb over indirect heat until the internal temperature reaches 135°F (57°C).
  5. Rest the lamb under tented foil for 15 minutes.
  6. Open the vents and bring the EGG up to 550°F (288°C). Sear the lamb quickly, rendering the fat cap if left on. Re-season with a pinch of salt if desired.
  7. Slice between the bones and serve.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Pull earlier for a rarer center (125-130°F / 52-54°C) or later for more doneness.
  • Keep the bones wrapped until after the sear for clean presentation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: These lamb ribs are cooked low and slow over gentle smoke, then wrapped to finish tender and glossy.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 4

  • Prep time: 20 minutes
  • Cook time: 4 hours
  • Total time: 4 hours 20 minutes (plus resting)
  • EGG setup: indirect smoke
  • EGG target temperature: 250-275F

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2 racks lamb ribs, membrane removed
  • 2 tbsp olive oil or mustard (binder)
  • 3 tbsp lamb-friendly BBQ rub (garlic, paprika, rosemary, black pepper, salt)
  • 2 tbsp butter
  • 2 tbsp brown sugar
  • 3 tbsp honey or maple syrup
  • 2 tbsp apple cider vinegar
  • Optional: 1 tbsp tomato paste for a stickier glaze

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Set up the EGG for indirect cooking at 250-275F with a small chunk of fruit wood.
  2. Pat ribs dry. Rub with oil or mustard, then coat with the BBQ rub. Rest 15-20 minutes.
  3. Smoke the ribs bone side down for 2 to 2.5 hours until the color is deep bronze. Spritz with water or apple juice if the surface looks dry.
  4. Lay out foil. Add butter, brown sugar, honey, and vinegar (plus tomato paste if using). Place ribs meat side down and wrap tightly.
  5. Return to the EGG meat side down for 60-90 minutes, until the ribs feel flexible and a skewer slides in easily.
  6. Unwrap and place ribs back on the EGG for 10-15 minutes to set the glaze.
  7. Rest 10 minutes, slice, and serve.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Lamb ribs vary in thickness; check tenderness rather than time.
  • If you prefer a drier bark, skip the wrap and cook uncovered until tender.

docs.title: Pork
docs.text:
• Carolina Pulled Pork Shoulder
  • The Four Saucemen BBQ Pork Ribs
  • The Four Saucemen BBQ Pulled Pork

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Recipe type: Main Cuisine: American Prep time: 20 min Cook time: 8-10 hours Total time: 8-10 hours Serves: 8

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Pork:

  • 1 tbsp American mustard (French's classic yellow)
  • 4 kg bone-in Boston butt / pork butt (not frozen)

Spritz:

  • 1 L clear apple juice
  • 150 ml apple cider vinegar
  • 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
  • 1.5 L spray bottle

Rub (optional) or use your favorite rub (The Four Saucemen Pork Rub):

  • 1 1/2 tbsp sweet smoked paprika
  • 1 tbsp paprika
  • 1 1/2 tbsp kosher salt (do not use iodized table salt)
  • 2 tsp cracked black pepper (avoid fine white pepper)
  • 2 tsp garlic granules
  • 2 tsp onion powder
  • 1 tsp ground cumin
  • 1 tsp cayenne pepper
  • 2 tsp soft brown sugar

Serve with:

  • Carolina mustard BBQ sauce
  • Sliced pickles
  • Burger buns or rolls

Equipment:

  • Apple wood chunks or splits
  • Heavy-duty foil (2 lengths, about 700-800 mm each)
  • Cooler (chilly bin) or Cambro

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Make the rub: Combine all dry ingredients except the brown sugar and kosher salt. Sift once, then sift again while adding the brown sugar. Add the kosher salt at the end and mix thoroughly.
  2. Set up your pit or BBQ for indirect cooking at 250F.
  3. Trim only hard fat and remove any skin if needed.
  4. Rub mustard over the pork, then apply the rub generously.
  5. Mix the spritz ingredients in the spray bottle and shake well.
  6. Add wood chunks to the fire. When the smoke thins to a light blue haze, place the pork on the grill. Cook 6-7 hours until the bark is dark. Start spritzing after the first 3 hours, then spritz every 45-60 minutes.
  7. When the internal temperature reaches about 170F, wrap. Lay two sheets of foil in a cross, spritz the pork, then wrap tightly and seal.
  8. Return to the pit/BBQ and cook another 2-3 hours until the internal temperature reaches 199-203F.
  9. Rest wrapped in a cooler or warm place for 1-2 hours.
  10. Unwrap in a foil tray, pour in the juices, remove the bone and cartilage, then pull the meat. Toss with the juices and serve with Carolina mustard BBQ sauce, pickles, and buns.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen BBQ Pork Ribs
Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• EGG setup: indirect smoke
  • EGG target temperature: 250-275F

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Pork Rib Rub
  • Wichita pork ribs
  • Olive oil or mustard (binder)
  • Heavy-duty foil
  • 50 g butter
  • 2 tbsp soft brown sugar
  • The Four Saucemen Rib Glaze

Spritz:

  • 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Defrost ribs overnight in the fridge. Remove the thin membrane on the bone side.
  2. Set up the EGG for indirect cooking at 250-275F with two pieces of smoking wood.
  3. Apply a thin layer of olive oil or mustard. Coat generously with pork rib rub and let it sweat for 30 minutes.
  4. Place ribs bone side down and smoke uncovered for 2 hours, spritzing every hour. The ribs should be dark mahogany (2.5 hours max).
  5. On foil, place butter and brown sugar and smear with rib glaze. Place ribs meat side down and wrap tightly.
  6. Cook meat side down for another 1 hour 15 minutes. Ribs should feel bendy.
  7. Rest wrapped for 15-20 minutes. Warm the rib glaze.
  8. Unwrap, glaze the meat side, and return to the smoker for 10-15 minutes to set.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: • Check tenderness with a bamboo skewer. If it feels tight, wrap a little longer.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen BBQ Pulled Pork
Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• EGG setup: indirect smoke
  • EGG target temperature: 250-275F

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Pork Rib Rub
  • 4-5 kg pork butt or shoulder
  • Olive oil or mustard (binder)
  • Foil tray large enough for the pork and foil to cover
  • 100 g butter
  • 100 ml clear apple juice
  • 100 ml lager-style beer
  • The Four Saucemen Rib Glaze

Spritz:

  • 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Set up the EGG for indirect cooking at 250-275F with two pieces of smoking wood.
  2. Trim any hard fat on the shoulder. Apply a thin layer of olive oil or mustard and coat with pork rib rub.
  3. Smoke uncovered for 3-4 hours, spritzing every hour. Target about 160F internal.
  4. Prepare a foil tray with apple juice, beer, and butter at room temperature. Place the pork in the tray and cover tightly with foil.
  5. Return to the EGG until internal temperature reaches 205F. Probe for tenderness; you can take it to 210F.
  6. Let steam escape for 5 minutes, then cover and rest in a towel-wrapped cooler for at least 45 minutes (preferably 1.5 hours).
  7. Uncover, remove the bone, and pull the pork. Drizzle with rib glaze and season as needed.

docs.text:
• Easy Argentinian Chimichurri Sauce
  • Ssamjang Korean Dipping Sauce
  • Vermouth Jus Gras

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Bright, herby chimichurri with a mix of fresh herbs and a light lemon bite.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 bunch flat-leaf parsley
  • 1 bunch cilantro (coriander)
  • 1 bunch fresh oregano
  • 4-5 sprigs thyme (leaves only)
  • 2-3 cloves garlic
  • Juice of 1 lemon
  • 1 mild-to-medium chili
  • Olive oil, to blend
  • Salt, to taste

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Wash and dry the herbs. Roughly chop and place in a food processor.
  2. Add chopped chili, garlic, salt, and lemon juice.
  3. Pulse until herbs are finely chopped. Do most of the blending before adding oil.
  4. With the motor running on medium, drizzle in olive oil until the mixture is spoonable and glossy.
  5. Avoid over-processing after adding oil to prevent the sauce from turning cloudy.
  6. Scoop into a bowl and serve. Keeps in the fridge for several hours.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Savory, spicy, and nutty dipping sauce for grilled meats.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Recipe type: Dipping sauce
  • Cuisine: Korean
  • Prep time: 10 minutes
  • Total time: 10 minutes
  • Serves: 4

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 32 g doenjang (fermented soybean paste)
  • 21 g gochujang (Korean chili paste)
  • 1 scallion, chiffonade
  • 32 g onion, minced
  • 5 g honey
  • 5 g toasted sesame seeds
  • 5 g sesame oil
  • 2.5 g lemon juice (or lime for a sharper finish)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Add scallion and onion to a small bowl.
  2. Add remaining ingredients and mix until fully combined.
  3. Transfer to a serving bowl and cover until needed.

Notes: This keeps for up to 7 days in the fridge. Great with BBQ, especially beef and pork.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A rich, glossy demi-glace sauce brightened with dry vermouth and cream.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Recipe type: Sauce
  • Cuisine: French
  • Prep time: 10 minutes
  • Cook time: 10 minutes (may vary)
  • Total time: 20 minutes
  • Yield: About 100 ml (roughly 6 small servings)

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 30 g salted butter (good quality)
  • 1 shallot, fine brunoise
  • 45 ml dry vermouth
  • 500 g demi-glace cubes (frozen)
  • 30 ml full-fat cream
  • Kosher salt, to taste
  • Black pepper, to taste

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Finely brunoise the shallot and set aside.
  2. Heat a skillet over medium heat, add butter, then soften the shallot for about 5 minutes without coloring.
  3. Add vermouth and simmer, scraping the pan to dissolve any fond, until almost evaporated.
  4. Add demi-glace cubes and simmer 5-7 minutes until melted and glossy.
  5. Stir in cream and simmer 2-4 minutes until the sauce turns a rich medium brown.
  6. Adjust consistency by reducing further if needed, then season with salt and pepper.
  7. Strain through a fine mesh strainer and serve.

• Mexican Street Corn
  • Sprits
  • The Perfect Blooming Onion

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Grilled elote finished with a creamy lime rub, cheese, and herbs.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Recipe type: Side
  • Cuisine: Mexican
  • Prep time: 5 minutes
  • Cook time: 20 minutes
  • Total time: 25 minutes
  • Serves: 6

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 6 ears of corn, shucked and cleaned
  • 115 g (1/2 cup) mayonnaise
  • 77 g (about 1/3 cup) of your favorite BBQ rub
  • 1 clove garlic, minced
  • Grated cotija or Parmesan (cheddar works in a pinch)
  • Fresh cilantro, chopped (reserve some for garnish)
  • 2 tbsp lime juice
  • Zest of 1 lime
  • Lime wedges, to serve
  • 10 g salted butter, cubed

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Preheat grill to 400-450 F.
  2. Grill corn, turning often, until lightly charred all over, about 10 minutes.
  3. In a bowl, whisk mayonnaise, cilantro, garlic, rub, lime zest, and lime juice. Taste and adjust salt if needed.
  4. Wrap corn in foil with butter and cook 6-8 minutes more until tender.
  5. Open foil, brush with the crema, and sprinkle with cheese. Return to grill for 2-3 minutes.
  6. Garnish with cilantro and serve with lime wedges.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A simple spritz (sprits) blend for basting or spritzing during long cooks.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1 L Kerri apple juice (clear)
  • 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 cap apple cider vinegar
  • 2-3 tbsp brisket mop or BBQ sauce of your choice
  • Optional: Jack Daniel's Old No. 7 (a splash adds warmth)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Combine all ingredients and stir well.
  2. Strain through a fine sieve (a coffee filter works well).
  3. Pour into a spritz bottle and use as needed.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Prep time: 30 minutes
  • Cook time: 5-7 minutes
  • Total time: 50 minutes

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Batter:

  • 1 cup milk
  • 2 large eggs
  • 1 cup all-purpose flour (not self-rising)
  • 1 tbsp cornstarch, plus extra for sprinkling
  • 1/2 tbsp baking powder
  • 1 large white or brown onion
  • Canola oil, for frying

Dry mix:

  • 3 tsp kosher salt
  • 3 tsp coarse black pepper
  • 2 tsp garlic powder
  • 3 tsp ancho chili powder (or 1/3 tsp cayenne)
  • 2 tsp chili powder
  • 1 tsp ground cumin

Dipping sauce:

  • 1/2 cup mayonnaise
  • 1 tbsp ketchup
  • 2 tbsp horseradish
  • 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
  • 1/2 tbsp yellow mustard
  • 1 tsp smoked paprika
  • 1 tsp coarse black pepper
  • 1 tsp garlic powder

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Whisk the dipping sauce ingredients. Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes.
  2. Whisk milk and eggs in a large bowl.
  3. In another bowl, combine flour, baking powder, and dry mix.
  4. Heat enough oil in a deep pot to submerge the onion to 375 F (190 C).
  5. Trim the top of the onion so it sits flat, keeping the root intact. Peel the onion.
  6. With a sharp knife, make 6 cuts around the onion about 1/2 inch from the root, then make 6 more cuts between them.
  7. Gently spread the petals apart to form a bloom.
  8. Sprinkle lightly with cornstarch.
  9. Coat the onion in the dry mix, dip into the milk mixture, then coat in the dry mix again.
  10. Shake off excess flour and lower into hot oil.
  11. Fry 5-7 minutes until deep golden brown and crispy.
  12. Drain briefly and serve with the dipping sauce.

docs.title: Techniques
docs.text: • Big Green Egg Process

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A step-by-step process for lighting, stabilizing, and cleaning a Big Green Egg.

docs.title: Process
docs.text:
1. Open the top and bottom vents as wide as possible.
  2. Fill lump charcoal to the top of the inner firebox ceramic (to the bottom of the split between the firebox and fire ring).
  3. Light the charcoal using organic fire lighters or an electric blower. If using fire lighters, place three around the charcoal, light them, build a small teepee of charcoal, and leave the lid open for maximum oxygen. If using an electric blower, hold it about 1 inch away from the charcoal for about 4 minutes.
  4. With the charcoal lit and the lid open, insert the ConvEGGtor legs down to preheat it.
  5. As the temperature climbs to about 20F below target, close the top and bottom vents halfway. Wearing heat gloves, flip the ConvEGGtor so legs are up, add the cooking grid, and close the lid.
  6. Let the EGG settle. When it starts to rise above target, close the vents by another 50 percent (about 25 percent open). Let it stabilize again.
  7. Once stable, close the vents to about a finger-width (or slightly less).
  8. The EGG should hold temperature for the entire cook.
  9. When the food reaches the desired internal temperature, remove it and close the vents to extinguish the fire.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Before the next cook, use the ash tool to knock charcoal around, clear ash into the bottom chamber, and rake it out. The ash will be cold the next day and can be used in the garden.
  • For roasts, use a roasting pan to avoid mess on the ConvEGGtor. For ribs, steaks, or thighs, place foil over the ConvEGGtor to catch drips.
  • Clean the grill by washing and drying. For ceramics, never use water; brush them down so ash drops into the charcoal.
